body:
Recieved 7.7 ish Lib, 0 Right, and .5ish left.  While the Lib part is probably accurate, I dont think the left part is.

My guess as to which question that brought this result was the one about business regulation- I feel that after a certain level businesses will form monopolies and destroy competition, therefore some regulations are needed.

body: Doubtful that it'll take off. It's not like I came up with the idea or anything, I just made the test for it. And none of my github repos have exactly hit the algorithm the right way yet, including this one. Someone I know has like 20-30 repos and only one of them ever got any attention at all (which was pure luck because they have better ones) and it still only has about 3 stars. There's another person who gets a lot of views on their repos but that's only because they're the kind of person who always gets popular everywhere they go for some reason.

post.title: I fixed the questions on my political triangle test (I think). Let me know if you still have any problems with it.

body:
I'd invert it, so the authoritarian is at the top like the traditional compass. 

And..... yeah. I honestly agree with the idea.   It's more like a giant U-shape. Where the extreamists use authoritarian means to enforce their ideology. While moderates on either sides are more relaxed and let people do their own thing. Another name for that is liberty.  

The 4-part political compass has always been bullshit.   ....And this triangle is also falling into the bullshit that there's a distinct right and left.  What do you call someone that wants economic controls but with social freedom? Is that right or left?   How about two people with identical views about how the nation ought to be run, but they disagree on how much they should interfere with foreign affairs? Or the taxing capital gain taxes as income tax? Is that right or left?   It's all bullshit meant to divide us and gives idiots an easy means of tribalism.
body_html:
I'd invert it, so the authoritarian is at the top like the traditional compass.

And..... yeah. I honestly agree with the idea. It's more like a giant U-shape. Where the extreamists use authoritarian means to enforce their ideology. While moderates on either sides are more relaxed and let people do their own thing. Another name for that is liberty.

The 4-part political compass has always been bullshit. ....And this triangle is also falling into the bullshit that there's a distinct right and left. What do you call someone that wants economic controls but with social freedom? Is that right or left? How about two people with identical views about how the nation ought to be run, but they disagree on how much they should interfere with foreign affairs? Or the taxing capital gain taxes as income tax? Is that right or left? It's all bullshit meant to divide us and gives idiots an easy means of tribalism.

body: On the triangle, right means legislated hierarchy and inequality, and left means forced equality. Both are auth beliefs. On the compass left means socialism and right means free market, though how they actually use it is extremely inconsistent. I feel like the division of economic and conservative vs progressive axis was kind of pointless and still disregards non-statist beliefs, so that's why I created the triangle test.
body_html: On the triangle, right means legislated hierarchy and inequality, and left means forced equality. Both are auth beliefs. On the compass left means socialism and right means free market, though how they actually use it is extremely inconsistent. I feel like the division of economic and conservative vs progressive axis was kind of pointless and still disregards non-statist beliefs, so that's why I created the triangle test.

body:
>How should business and corporations be regulated?

...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights"   is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.   

The censorship one is really on the nose.   I've got way more nuanced views than any of these answers provide.  If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians.    If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses" then you'd find a lot more people just don't fit on the graph at all because the right-left thing is bullshit and we need more nuanced policy than "RED GOOD, BLUE BAD".
body_html:
How should business and corporations be regulated?

...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights" is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.

The censorship one is really on the nose. I've got way more nuanced views than any of these answers provide. If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians. If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses" then you'd find a lot more people just don't fit on the graph at all because the right-left thing is bullshit and we need more nuanced policy than "RED GOOD, BLUE BAD".

What do you call someone that wants economic controls but with social freedom? Is that right or left?   How about two people with identical views about how the nation ought to be run, but they disagree on how much they should interfere with foreign affairs? Or the taxing capital gain taxes as income tax? Is that right or left?   It's all bullshit meant to divide us and gives idiots an easy means of tribalism.

body:
On this triangle right just means hierarchy and left just means forced equality. It's just a test for your general attitude towards politics. For example, someone who wants economic regulation but is otherwise libertarian would simply be placed on the left side of the libertarian quadrant. It's about the philosophy governing your beliefs, not specific issues, and that's explained on the test page. If you want a test on every granular area of politics try 8values or 6 triangles or something.

And personally I think the economic and social division is BS and it doesn't account for non-statist beliefs.
body_html:
On this triangle right just means hierarchy and left just means forced equality. It's just a test for your general attitude towards politics. For example, someone who wants economic regulation but is otherwise libertarian would simply be placed on the left side of the libertarian quadrant. It's about the philosophy governing your beliefs, not specific issues, and that's explained on the test page. If you want a test on every granular area of politics try 8values or 6 triangles or something.

And personally I think the economic and social division is BS and it doesn't account for non-statist beliefs.

body:
> ...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights" is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.

Well "infringe on others' rights" is typically geared more towards using force, as in doing more than just firing people or refusing their services to a customer. So like, they can't go out and kill bad reviewers or something. The former usually refers to the interests of labor unions and worker ownership of the company and such.

> If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians. If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses"

Quite a lot of people believe the censorship ones actually. You have to remember Ruqqus itself is skewed well into the libertarian section, but in the real world, especially outside the US you'll definitely run into crowds that don't believe in free speech. I also tried to word the options to make them only refer to extreme types of said speech, ie the "hard cases" you mentioned. I don't expect that anyone would openly admit they want to ban *every* tiny thing they don't like, except maybe Kim Jong Un.
body_html:
...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights" is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.

Well "infringe on others' rights" is typically geared more towards using force, as in doing more than just firing people or refusing their services to a customer. So like, they can't go out and kill bad reviewers or something. The former usually refers to the interests of labor unions and worker ownership of the company and such.

If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians. If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses"

Quite a lot of people believe the censorship ones actually. You have to remember Ruqqus itself is skewed well into the libertarian section, but in the real world, especially outside the US you'll definitely run into crowds that don't believe in free speech. I also tried to word the options to make them only refer to extreme types of said speech, ie the "hard cases" you mentioned. I don't expect that anyone would openly admit they want to ban every tiny thing they don't like, except maybe Kim Jong Un.

parent.body:
>How should business and corporations be regulated?

...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights"   is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.   

The censorship one is really on the nose.   I've got way more nuanced views than any of these answers provide.  If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians.    If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses" then you'd find a lot more people just don't fit on the graph at all because the right-left thing is bullshit and we need more nuanced policy than "RED GOOD, BLUE BAD".

How should business and corporations be regulated?

...But "as long as they don't infringe other's rights" is the exact same thing as "prevent exploitive practices and mistreat workers".... just with catch-phrases of different political camps.

The censorship one is really on the nose. I've got way more nuanced views than any of these answers provide. If there's only three choices and all are extreme views of absolute SJW, Nazi, or libertarian, then SHOCK you're going to see a lot of libertarians. If you let people answer "well I want a mix of carrot AND stick, in reasonable amounts with a cut-off threshold for hard cases and different paths for different offenses" then you'd find a lot more people just don't fit on the graph at all because the right-left thing is bullshit and we need more nuanced policy than "RED GOOD, BLUE BAD".

body: Most tests are like that, and I actually think it's beneficial in case someone doesn't understand one of the options, they can always look at that to see what I'm probably getting at with it.
body_html: Most tests are like that, and I actually think it's beneficial in case someone doesn't understand one of the options, they can always look at that to see what I'm probably getting at with it.

parent.body: The test answers should be in random order, otherwise people catch on which are the "left" and "right" answers and don't read them carefully.
parent.body_html: The test answers should be in random order, otherwise people catch on which are the "left" and "right" answers and don't read them carefully.

post.title: I fixed the questions on my political triangle test (I think). Let me know if you still have any problems with it.

body: I agree 100%. If people are going to be biased in a triangle quizz then they're going to fudge it some other way if the answers are random. At least this way it's harder to misinterpret what you might be saying; 'What best describes your ideal form of government?' I initially read the last option as their actions would align with their nation's ideologies, but upon rereading and its position I realised that it was stressing the 'enforcing' aspect which wasn't what I was going for.

body:
Nope, there's no economic axis on the triangle.

> The political triangle is an improvement over the traditional political compass. *While the original test attempted to harmonize the libertarian American right with the traditional hierarchical right by separating the economic and social axis*, this still resulted in quite a few problems. For example, anti-statism and progressive statism were often conflated with each other as "libertarian". The right wing was described as laissez-faire free markets, but in practice was used to mean crony capitalism. *This test, instead of trying to divide social vs economic beliefs, recognizes that there are three different main philosophies at the core of political systems: the (traditional) right favors hierarchy, the elite classes, and a well defined social structure; the libertarian side (the American right) esteems individual liberty as the top priority; and the left seeks equality, community, and collectivism.*
body_html:
Nope, there's no economic axis on the triangle.

The political triangle is an improvement over the traditional political compass. While the original test attempted to harmonize the libertarian American right with the traditional hierarchical right by separating the economic and social axis, this still resulted in quite a few problems. For example, anti-statism and progressive statism were often conflated with each other as "libertarian". The right wing was described as laissez-faire free markets, but in practice was used to mean crony capitalism. This test, instead of trying to divide social vs economic beliefs, recognizes that there are three different main philosophies at the core of political systems: the (traditional) right favors hierarchy, the elite classes, and a well defined social structure; the libertarian side (the American right) esteems individual liberty as the top priority; and the left seeks equality, community, and collectivism.

parent.body: I was under the impression that left and right were economic stances
parent.body_html: I was under the impression that left and right were economic stances

post.title: I fixed the questions on my political triangle test (I think). Let me know if you still have any problems with it.

body:
> What is your stance on immigration and border policy?

Immigrants who are estimated to benefit the economy should be allowed to enter and assimilated. I.e. they should be allowed to enter and be subject to **more** strict rules than everyone else.

BTW Your score is:

2.78 left

0.56 right

5 libertarian
